text: haha you are clearly very switched on!!
Woop Woop! that is a great logo congrats. And you are using Prospela purple hehe I love purple
RE: CV I understand. So maybe you'd like to do a very basic first draft with the experience etc you think is worth highlighting and then I can review it in detail for you?
I'd be happy to share my CV to give you some insights / inspiration if that would be useful. Just let me know!

Understand if you are too busy atm to create a CV but it will definitely help you understand yourself better - it's a good process to go through to understand where your strengths and weaknesses lie. Of course, will also help with applying to jobs. Before we can approach companies, we'd need a CV for you...

Apprenticeship vs uni is a good question. It isn't necessarily "better" or "worse as it completely depends on what the end goal is. As you can imagine, what might be a quick route into a career like cyber security would look very different to someone who wants to go into investment banking!

In the past, there has been a stigma around apprenticeships i.e. that it is for people that dont get the grades... but this is changing. As companies demand more technical skills, work experience can sometimes be more highly valued than grades ... hence why an apprenticeship might be very useful. University is a traditional approach into top careers, but of course there are "good" and "bad" universities so even that depends!
What grades are you expecting for A-Levels? Would help me advice you better re: uni vs. apprenticeships

Top universities obv have a lot of competition to get in so they would want to see top grades in specific subjects.
Medium/low quality universities (with less competition for places) & Apprenticeship employers would probably be more leniant on grades, but might want to see work experience / a genuine interest in the subject area / job
